runs.text: Display the Sound-Spelling Cards for closed syllables (napkin) and open syllables (zero). Review that a syllable is a word part.
Explain that a closed syllable ends in a consonant and usually has a short vowel sound. Model with
Explain that an open syllable ends in a vowel and usually has a long vowel soundthe vowel says its name. Model with
Model how to blend the syllables in these words:
. Explain how the closed syllables have short vowel sounds. Then model blending the syllables for
. Explain how the open syllables have long vowel sounds.

to these syllables to make words: -
. List the words as they form them. Discuss their meanings and spellings. Then have students add

as they say the sounds for each syllable. Then have them write the words
(Add words with skills your students need to review.)
Use the first two words in the first line.
What do you notice thats different in these two words?

Then have students chorally read the remaining words in each line. For the first time through the blending lines, point to each letter or spelling as students say the sound. Then run your finger under the letters as students blend the sounds orally. Finally, have students say the word.
Corrective Feedback: Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed spelling, stating the sound or sounds, having student repeat, then re-blending the word together.
Read Aloud: Why Arent All Bird Beaks the Same?
Display the photos on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
Display the Sound-Spelling Card for closed syllables
Review that a closed syllable ends in a consonant and usually has a short vowel sound
. An open syllable ends in a vowel and usually has a long vowel soundthe vowel says its name
. Explain how the closed syllables have short vowel sounds. Then model blending the syllables:
. Explain how the open syllables have long vowel sounds.
Have students list words that begin with closed syllable
(e.g., sandwich, sandbox, sandal). List the words and discuss the meanings and spellings. Then have students list words that begin with open syllable
Have students select two of the words from the list and write sentences for them.
Corrective Feedback: Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed sound-spelling, stating it, having students repeat, then re-blending the word together.
Write the high-frequency words one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you. Guide students to orally segment the word. Discuss known and unknown word parts.
What sounds do you hear in
? (/w/ /u/ /n/) What letters do you see? (o-n-e) The word
doesnt follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling. The word
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Finally, have students use each word in an oral sentence.
Display the Sound-Spelling Card for closed syllables
Review that a closed syllable ends in a consonant and usually has a short vowel sound
. An open syllable ends in a vowel and usually has a long vowel soundthe vowel says its name
Model how to create words with the closed syllable
(e.g., admit, submit, mitten). Review that closed syllables end in a consonant and have a short vowel sound. Then model creating words with open syllable
(e.g., recent, react, reread). This syllable does not end in a consonant and makes a long vowel sound.
Use the Lesson 2 blending words to apply the skill.
Pause before each word for students to whisper-blend it, before having them read it together aloud.

Use the new blending lines. Focus attention on modeling for students how to transition from known one-syllable words to multisyllabic words.
When completed, have students select two words.
Ask them to write on paper or a dry-erase board a sentence for each word.
Display the High-Frequency Word Cards one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you.
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Point out the irregular spelling of
. Highlight the sound for the letter

Remind students that dividing a longer word into syllables can help them figure out how to read it. A closed syllable ends in a consonant and usually has a short vowel sound. An open syllable ends in a vowel and usually has a long vowel soundthe vowel says its name. Write the word
and draw a line to separate syllables:
Model how to blend the syllables
. Have students follow your model to blend syllables and read the word.
(plas/tic). Guide students to divide each word into syllables, read the syllables, then blend the syllables to read the words.
Display each word, and guide students to read it.
Place sorting cards  with these labels in a pocket chart: Closed First Syllable and Open First Syllable.
Model how to sort the words
Have student partners sort the remaining words at their seats.
When completed, have students tell you how to sort the words in the pocket chart. Then have students chorally read the words in each column of the sort.
Ask students what they notice about the words.
If necessary, point out that closed syllables have short vowel sounds, while open syllables usually have long vowel sounds.
Encourage students to look for words with closed and open syllables while reading. Highlight these words as you encounter them.

Write the following words divided into syllables:
. Model how to blend the syllables and read the words. Point out which syllables are closed and which are open.

Use the new blending words. Focus attention on modeling for students how to transition from known one-syllable words to multisyllabic words. For the first time through, point to each letter or spelling as students say the sound. Then run your finger under the letters as students blend the syllables orally. Finally, have students say the word.

Display the High-Frequency Word Cards one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you. Guide students to orally segment the word. Then discuss key features of each word to focus students attention on known (regular) and unknown (irregular) word parts.
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Finally, have students use each word in an oral sentence.

Use the new blending words. Focus attention on modeling for students how to transition from known one-syllable words to multisyllabic words. For the first time through, point to each letter or spelling as students say the sound. Then run your finger under the letters as students blend the syllables orally. Finally, have students say the word.
Display the High-Frequency Word Cards one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you.
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Read, Build, Write: have, is, jump, my, one, put, the, want, what, you

Display the High-Frequency Word Cards. Call out one word. Have students find the matching word card, repeat the word, and spell it aloud. Then have students build each word with Letter Cards. Extend the learning with one or more of the following activities:
Provide a sentence starter or frame for each word. Have students write and complete the sentences. Then have them read their sentences to a partner (e.g.,
Make a word using Letter Cards. Have students read and spell aloud the word. Then mix the Letter Cards. Have students fix the spelling.
Display the Sound-Spelling Card for closed syllables
. Review that a closed syllable ends in a consonant and usually has a short vowel sound
. An open syllable ends in a vowel and usually has a long vowel soundthe vowel says its name
Use the Lesson 6 blending words to apply the skill. When completed, guide students to find and circle all the closed syllables. Then have them put a box around the open syllables.

Read Aloud: Bugs Beware! Sneaky Plants Have Set Their Traps
Display the photos on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions.
Display the Sound-Spelling Card for closed syllables
. Review that a closed syllable ends in a consonant and usually has a short vowel sound
. An open syllable ends in a vowel and usually has a long vowel soundthe vowel says its name
Use the Lesson 6 blending words to quickly review the skill.
When completed, have students select two multisyllabic blending words. At least one word should have an open syllable.
Ask them to write a sentence for each word on paper or a dry-erase board.
Review closed and open syllables in the two words chosen. Have students circle the closed syllables and put a box around the open syllables.
Explain that some words begin with three-letter blends such as
Point out that each sound in a blend is pronounced, but the sounds are blended closely together.
Model how to build the word
. Guide students to identify the initial 3-letter blend. Model how to read the new words formed.
Have students see how many words they can make with the initial 3-letter blends
. List the words as they form them. Discuss their meanings.
to name what is inside of a peach
to name a large container used for cooking.
to name the opposite of cold.
to name a place to stay.
Read, Build, Write: have, is, jump, my one, put, the, want, what, you
Call out one word. Have students find the matching word card, repeat the word, and spell it aloud.
Then have students build each word with Letter Cards. Mix the Letter Cards, and have students rebuild it as they point to and say the letters.
